structured_data.name: ODYSSEE
structured_data.description: ODYSSEE is an external data source accessible through the European Environment Agency (EEA) data and maps portal. The dataset appears to be related to energy efficiency and environmental monitoring across European Union member countries and EEA member countries. The portal provides access to various environmental topics including energy, climate change mitigation, energy efficiency, and related sustainability indicators.
structured_data.granularity: National - European Union and EEA member countries

structured_data.name: ODYSSEE MURE Key Indicators
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query tool with map-based country selection and Excel export functionality
structured_data.description: A data tool presenting approximately 30 key energy efficiency indicators developed within the ODYSSEE MURE project, covering data from 1990 until 2025. Indicators are organized by sector (macro, industry, transport, households, and services) and include metrics such as energy saving rates, energy intensity, specific consumption, and modal split. The tool allows users to view absolute values for a specific year and average trends since 2000 (%/year). Data can be exported to Excel format. Last updated October 2025.

structured_data.name: ODYSSEE Database
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface with advanced query capabilities; free access for EU Ministries, Concerted Action EED, EED Committee Members, and EU universities/research centres; subscription available for other users; login and registration available
subsector: Commercial and Institutional Buildings and Facilities
structured_data.data_format: Database with tables and graphs; results available in multiple units; downloadable brochure available
structured_data.description: The ODYSSEE database contains detailed energy consumption by end-use and their drivers, as well as energy efficiency and CO2 related indicators. Data is provided by national representatives such as energy agencies and statistical organizations from all EU countries, Switzerland, and Serbia. The database includes macro-level data (primary consumption, final consumption, demography, GDP), industry branch data (chemical, metals, minerals, paper, food, textile, machinery, transport equipment, wood, mining, construction), transport modes (road, rail, water, air), residential end-uses (space heating, water heating, cooking, appliances), and services & agriculture branches (hotels, health, education, administration, retail, offices, agriculture). Latest available data is continuously updated by national representatives.
structured_data.granularity: National level for all EU countries, Switzerland, and Serbia

structured_data.name: EEA greenhouse gases — data viewer
structured_data.description: Data viewer on Total greenhouse gas emissions and removals of the European Union, based on data reported by EU Member States under the EU Governance Regulation. Published by the European Environment Agency (EEA) on 16 April 2025, with last modification on 16 May 2025. Provides comprehensive greenhouse gas inventory data for EU countries.

decision_log.summary: Plan for European Union with 12 structured queries.

decision_log.summary: Reviewed 6 documents from authoritative EU sources. Four documents are highly promising for GHGI data extraction: the EEA ODYSSEE database and key indicators portal contain detailed energy efficiency and consumption data by sector; the Reportnet dataflows page lists official EU reporting obligations including greenhouse gas emissions and energy-related data; the EEA greenhouse gases viewer provides direct access to EU member state GHG emissions data; and the ETXtra page aggregates multiple authoritative sources for EU ETS and emissions data. The first document (EEA ODYSSEE external link) appears to be a navigation page with limited content. Overall, this batch contains multiple high-quality official sources directly relevant to stationary energy sector GHGI data.
decision_log.reasoning: This batch contains multiple authoritative EU sources with strong indicators of structured GHGI and energy data. The ODYSSEE database and key indicators are specifically designed for energy efficiency monitoring across EU countries with detailed sectoral breakdowns. Reportnet provides access to official EU reporting dataflows on greenhouse gas emissions and energy. The EEA greenhouse gases viewer offers direct GHG emissions data by member state. ETXtra aggregates multiple official sources including EU ETS data and EEA reports. All sources are from recognized EU institutions (EEA, European Commission, ODYSSEE-MURE project). These documents warrant full extraction to identify specific datasets, tables, and access points for stationary energy sector GHGI data.

decision_log.summary: Four highly relevant EU-level GHGI data sources have been identified from credible European institutions (EEA, Eurostat-affiliated ODYSSEE MURE). The extracted data includes both energy efficiency indicators and comprehensive greenhouse gas inventory data covering multiple sectors (stationary energy, transportation, waste, IPPU, AFOLU). All sources are official EU portals with national-level granularity appropriate for GHGI purposes. The EEA greenhouse gases data viewer is particularly significant as it directly addresses EU Member State GHG reporting under the EU Governance Regulation. Data appears current (last updated April-May 2025 and October 2025). The main limitation is that the extraction provides source descriptions rather than actual emission values or detailed methodological documentation, but this is expected at the discovery phase.
decision_log.reasoning: The search plan has successfully identified official, credible EU-level GHGI data sources from authoritative institutions (EEA, ODYSSEE MURE). The EEA greenhouse gases data viewer is the primary official source for EU GHG inventory reporting under EU Governance Regulation. ODYSSEE MURE provides complementary energy consumption and efficiency data essential for stationary energy sector analysis. All sources offer national-level data for EU Member States, which is appropriate and sufficient for GHGI purposes. The sources are current, accessible via web interfaces, and explicitly designed for GHG and energy monitoring. No critical gaps have been identified that would require additional searching. The next phase should proceed to data extraction from these identified sources rather than conducting additional searches.
